user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemCreate:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemCreate(osal_id_t *sem_id, const char *sem_name, uint32 options)
{
    int32                       return_code;
    OS_object_token_t           token;
    OS_mutex_internal_record_t *mutex;

    /* Check parameters */
    OS_CHECK_POINTER(sem_id);
    OS_CHECK_APINAME(sem_name);

    /* Note - the common ObjectIdAllocate routine will lock the object type and leave it locked. */
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew(LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        mutex = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_mutex_table, token);

        /* Reset the table entry and save the name */
        OS_OBJECT_INIT(token, mutex, obj_name, sem_name);

        /* Now call the OS-specific implementation.  This reads info from the table. */
        return_code = OS_MutSemCreate_Impl(&token, options);

        /* Check result, finalize record, and unlock global table. */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew(return_code, &token, sem_id);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_MutSemCreate:
#define OS_OBJECT_INIT(tok, ref, namefield, nameval) {memset(ref,0,sizeof(*ref));strncpy(ref->namefield,nameval,sizeof(ref->namefield)-1);OS_ObjectIdGlobalFromToken(&tok)->name_entry=ref->namefield;}
...
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
typedef struct
{
    char      obj_name[OS_MAX_API_NAME];
    osal_id_t last_owner;
} OS_mutex_internal_record_t
...
OS_mutex_internal_record_t OS_mutex_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
#define OS_CHECK_POINTER(ptr) BUGCHECK((ptr)!=NULL,OS_INVALID_POINTER)
...
#define OS_CHECK_APINAME(str) OS_CHECK_STRING(str,OS_MAX_API_NAME,OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG)
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew(return_code, &token, sem_id);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 8.13 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No — in this code &token is a mutable object token that is created/used by the allocation/finalization APIs (OS_ObjectIdAllocateNew, OS_MutSemCreate_Impl, OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew). Those routines are expected to modify or consume the token (e.g. fill in or finalize its contents), so the pointer must be non-const. A violation would occur only if OS_ObjectIdFinalizeNew (or the other called routines) actually do not modify the token and their prototypes could/should accept a pointer to const; in that case passing a non-const pointer would violate Rule 8.13.
